author: lucidvein
body:
Not too shabby OP.  I have all of those except Coca Cola, Pepsi, and McDonalds since most of their stuff is based on unhealthy products even w/ their market penetration I'm not convinced society is heading in that direction.

I can post my top 20 holdings for you.  I've been lucky enough to typically beat the S&P.  40% of my portfolio are in mutual funds but my individual picks are:

1. Amazon: 6.6% - #1 Ecommerce subscription \[moat\], hardware, twitch, ecosystem
2. Johnson and Johnson: 6% - #1 Pharma giant
3. Next Era Energy: 5.8% - Moated energy utility in SE USA, going 20% solar too soon
4. Google: 5.0% - #1 Search engine, Data monster, Youtube, Invests in SpaceX etc.
5. Gold: 5% - Hedge
6. Intel: 4.6% - Chipset King.  Might dip w/ AMD on rise.
7. Cadence Design: 4% - Electronic Design Automation
8. Apple: 3.7% - World class phone maker, ecosystem, cult following w/ services
9. Microsoft: 3.4% - Azure, Office Suite, Windows, Solid
10. Lockheed Martin: 3.4% - Defense spending won't be going away. Industry leader.
11. Illumina: 3% - Genetic Analysis, human health advancement
12. Wheaton Precious Metals: 2.8% - Favorite precious metals miner
13. United Health Group: 2.8% - Industry leader in Health Insurance
14. Waste Management: 2.6% - Garbage isn't going to go away anytime soon
15. Market Axcess: 2.5% -  Electronic trading platform for bonds/fixed income
16. Disney: 2.3% - Media & entertainment giant
17. Nvidia 1.8% - #1 video card company, gaming, business visualization, solid AI r&d
18. Raytheon: 1.5% - More Defense
19. Visa: 1.4% - Fintech & market penetration
20. Adobe: 1.4% - Subscription service for top graphic suite
21. Crispr: 1.1% - Genetic Editing R&D and interesting possibilities

Some other stocks I own and don't mind recommending are HD, LULU, BLK, SPCE (can't fight the memes), Alibaba, Tencent, Qdel, Fortinet, Berkshire, Paypal, Texas Instruments, Qcom, some beat down covid stocks like RCL & Boeing.

author: NocNocNoc19
body: Im not sure how much money you have to start with. Vanguard index funds have been my overall best investment. Voo, VTI, VT. if you dont have enough to buy whole shares of those robin hood offers fractional shares but I have never gone that route so I honestly don't know how good of a thing they are. Other then that do a lot of research. Read a lot. Dont buy and think your going to sell again any time soon. Ive only been actually investing for about 2 years. In that time I have only sold 1 position because I no longer liked the investment long term. Everything else i have bought with the intent to hold for 10+ years baring something extremely unforeseen. I buy a lot of blue chips and companies im somewhat familiar with as well. I work in tech so I own cisco, palo alto, fortinet, netapp because I work with there products a lot. But i probably only own about 30 individual companies and over 50% of my portfolio is in those index funds i mentioned earlier. Is this winning advice, I have no idea but its been working for me.

author: shacoand2boxes
body:
Akamai Technologies stock is trading higher Thursday after Cowen analyst Colby Synesael raised his rating on the content-delivery network company to Outperform from Market Perform, while upping his target price to $150 from $107.

Synesael is basically making the observation (which I made in an April Tech Trader column) that Akamai shares (ticker: AKAM) have not participated in the huge rally in internet infrastructure plays amid the Covid-19 pandemic. The analyst says there is now a "meaningful disconnect" between Akamai and other security and CDN stocks, despite its larger scale, higher profitability and " still solid growth." He sees Akamai as an "attractive way" to play long-term trends like cloud security and edge computing.

Synesael points out that the stock looks cheap relative to both security plays like Palo Alto Networks (PANW) and Fortinet (FTNT) and to other content- delivery networks, such as Cloudflare (NET), Fastly (FSLY), and Limelight Networks (LLNW). He argues that Covid-19 has served as a catalyst to Akamai's security and CDN businesses.

"We believe Covid-19 has resulted in increased demand for both its enterprise and internet security product offerings given the increase in the number of attacks across organizations and the internet," Synesael writes. "We believe Akamai's security business is an underappreciated component of its long- term growth opportunity and that as it becomes a larger portion of total revenue more investors are likely to start valuing it on its [sum of the parts] which we believe will result in a significant re-rating of the stock."

The analyst notes that there have been investor concerns about the company losing market share to peers like Fastly, but asserts that "the growth of competitors is more a function of an expanding opportunity for CDN providers rather than share stealing from Akamai."

Akamai shares were up 7%, at $113.78, in recent trading, while the S&P 500 was up 0.9%. The stock is up about 32% year to date, which is impressive growth -- except when compared with Cloudflare, which has more than doubled, and Fastly, which has more than quadrupled

author: TheTigersAreNotReal
body:
GLW: Glass manufacturer that is used in vials, phones, TVs, and other medical/commercial appliances. They have a contract to produce vials for Pfizer, and received a grant from the government to ensure that they will be able to produce enough vials for the future vaccine. Had their price target upgraded to $33 by Citigroup, currently oversold at $25.75

Don’t know when this thing is gonna moon again, but I hope it’s soon. Probably needs to announce another biomed contract to turn more heads. White knuckling these calls hoping the market realizes its value soon

author: math1024
body:
The main difference between 5G and the previous roll outs is just a lot more fiber and small cell antennas. I think the best 5G plays would be fiber companies like GLW, COMM, and OCC.

There's also been [legislation](https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Executive_Order_13858) promoting onshoring so you might want to focus on american manufacturers.
